article:
When I was about twelve I used to visit this elderly gentleman who was a volunteer counselor for the Boy Scouts . He would give us   _   until he thought we were skilled in a given subject. I did not know him long, but I   _   him for giving so much to the neighborhood,   _   when he was in poor health.
One day I made an appointment with him, but I   _   about it until some three hours later. I jumped on my bike and rode   _   to his home, all the while   _   about how poorly he must think of me. His wife   _   the door and I made a(n)   _   immediately, but I could tell that something was   _   . She paused and then told me her   _   had just died. Then she apologized for not having had time to   _   me. I left her home wondering if somehow my    _   to keep the appointment had   _   him so much that he died.
Some thirty years later I told this   _   to a friend. I said that though I had long since realized that my   _   had nothing to do with his   _   , I could not help wondering if I could have made a   _   had I shown up on time. My friend said that my not being there was probably meant to be,   _   the situation would have been too painful for me. Hearing her say that was like a huge wave hitting me and lifting this heavy weight I'd been   _   for years. Now whenever I think of that kind old gentleman, I think too of the   _   words of my friend.
